page.title: 05The Crynant Forest.
page.content: The Crynant Forest is one area of the{Forestry Commission's}large management that is controlled from the centre at Rheola in the Vale of Neath. The first planting of trees at Crynant was undertaken in 1930, the majority of trees planted being of a coniferous variety such as Sitka spruce, Japanese larch, Corsican pine and Scots pine. Deciduous trees are also planted too, willow, oak, birch, ash, alder and beech. The area of the Crynant Forest is approximately 2,440 hectares in which there are about 5 million trees. The main use of the wood from the forest is for timber in house building, furniture, chipboard and pulp wood for paper-making. There are seven men employed by the{Forestry Commission}and ten men privately sub-contracted at Crynant.
